images.copyright: Osaka at night, Japan (© wichianduangsri/Getty Images)
images.title: City of neon dreams
images.caption: The city of Osaka at night, Japan
images.desc: In the heart of Japan, where the past and future intertwine, lies a city pulsating with life and culture—Osaka. Traditionally an economic hub, Osaka has twice served briefly as the imperial capital, once in the 7th and once in the 8th century. It flourished culturally during the Edo period (1603–1867) and became a major industrial centre after the Meiji Restoration in 1868, which restored imperial rule to Japan.

og.title: The city of Osaka at night, Japan
og.desc: In the heart of Japan, where the past and future intertwine, lies a city pulsating with life and culture—Osaka. Traditionally an economic…

images.copyright: Bardenas Reales Biosphere Reserve and Natural Park, Bardenas, Navarra, Spain (© Aliaume Chapelle/Tandem Stills + Motion)
images.title: Breath-taking silence
images.caption: Bardenas Reales Biosphere Reserve and Natural Park, Navarra, Spain
images.desc: Within the scenic landscape of Navarra, northern Spain, the Bardenas Reales Biosphere Reserve and Natural Park is like a surrealist painting come to life! This park is renowned for its desert-like landscapes sculpted by millennia of erosion. Featuring rocky plateaus, canyons and whimsically shaped clay structures called cabezos, the park is a playground of geological wonders.

og.title: Bardenas Reales Biosphere Reserve and Natural Park, Navarra, Spain
og.desc: Within the scenic landscape of Navarra, northern Spain, the Bardenas Reales Biosphere Reserve and Natural Park is like a surrealist painting…

images.copyright: Skyline of Downtown Montreal, Quebec, Canada (© benedek/E+/Getty Images)
images.title: Lap after lap
images.caption: Canadian Grand Prix 2024
images.desc: Rev up your spirits because the Canadian Grand Prix is shifting into high gear! This Formula One showdown is all set to bring a rush of adrenaline to the Circuit Gilles Villeneuve in Montreal. Named after Canada's homegrown racing hero Gilles Villeneuve, the track has witnessed legendary moments, like Lewis Hamilton's maiden win in 2007, and Jacques Villeneuve racing across his father's namesake circuit. Each lap around the 4.361-kilometre circuit is as unpredictable as it is thrilling, with drivers navigating 70 laps with 14 turns each, including the infamous 'Wall of Champions'—a spot where many racing legends, like Michael Schumacher, have faced hardships.

og.title: Canadian Grand Prix 2024
og.desc: Rev up your spirits because the Canadian Grand Prix is shifting into high gear! This Formula One showdown is all set to bring a rush of…

images.copyright: Family of humpback whales, Dutch Harbor, Alaska (© Jude Newkirk/Amazing Aerial Agency)
images.title: Waves of hope
images.caption: World Oceans Day
images.desc: Today, let's embark on a watery adventure as we celebrate World Oceans Day. This day is about honouring and protecting the world's oceans and serves as a reminder of the critical role oceans play in supporting life on Earth. These gargantuan water bodies, after all, teem with wonders, from the tiniest plankton to the grandest whales like the humpbacks we see here. The oceans also produce almost half of the oxygen on our planet thanks to the photosynthesis of plankton—tiny plants, algae and bacteria. Moreover, they absorb a significant amount of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, helping mitigate the impacts of climate change caused by human activities.

og.title: World Oceans Day
og.desc: Today, let's embark on a watery adventure as we celebrate World Oceans Day. This day is about honouring and protecting the world's oceans…

images.copyright: Les Braves monument on Omaha Beach, Normandy, France (© Christopher Furlong/Getty Images)
images.title: D-Day: 80 years on
images.caption: The 80th anniversary of D-Day
images.desc: Eighty years ago, on the beaches of Normandy, northern France, an event unfolded that would alter the course of history. The day was June 6, 1944, a date forever etched in time as D-Day. It marked the launch of Operation Overlord, the ambitious Allied invasion that became a turning point in World War II. The audacious assault by sea, air and land involved nearly 160,000 troops.

og.desc: Eighty years ago, on the beaches of Normandy, northern France, an event unfolded that would alter the course of history. The day was June…

images.copyright: Masoala National Park in Madagascar (© Dennis van de Water/Shutterstock)
images.title: Happy b-earth-day!
images.caption: World Environment Day
images.desc: Happy World Environment Day! First celebrated back in 1973 with the theme 'Only One Earth', this event, organised by the United Nations, is all about encouraging people to help protect the environment. It is celebrated in over 143 countries around the world. This year's theme focuses on land restoration, desertification and drought resilience.

og.title: World Environment Day
og.desc: Happy World Environment Day! First celebrated back in 1973 with the theme 'Only One Earth', this event, organised by the United Nations, is…

images.copyright: Chestnut-headed bee-eaters, Bardia National Park, Nepal (© PACO COMO/Shutterstock)
images.title: Birds of a feather…
images.caption: Chestnut-headed bee-eater, Bardia National Park, Nepal
images.desc: It's not just a name. Chestnut-headed bee-eaters do spend their days swooping after stinging insects. As well as bees, they also feast on wasps, hornets and other bugs. The birds in today's image are in Bardia National Park in Nepal, but they're found across many other South Asian countries, from India and Bangladesh to Sri Lanka and Thailand. They catch their prey in mid-flight, returning to a perch where they can beat stinging insects to stun them, which makes them safe to eat. These birds are designed to hunt: their dazzling green plumage helps camouflage them in dappled jungle light, their curved beak is perfect for picking off insects with precision and their eyes can move individually, which makes them all the better for spotting bees.

images.copyright: Bicycles in Copenhagen, Denmark (© Alphotographic/Getty Images)
images.title: 'Two' tyred for a ride
images.caption: World Bicycle Day
images.desc: Bicycles are the best! An environmentally friendly form of transportation that is fun, good for your health, affordable, simple and durable. Once you learn to ride, you'll never forget how to wheel around. Thanks to Polish-American scientist Leszek Sibiliski's initiative, the United Nations declared June 3 World Bicycle Day in 2018.
